PersA-FL: Personalized Asynchronous Federated Learning

\nameMohammad Taha Toghania, Soomin Leeb, César A. Uribea This work was partly done while MTT interning at Yahoo! Research. Part of this material is based upon work supported by the National Science Foundation under Grants #2211815 and #2213568. Corresponding Author’s Email: mttoghani@rice.edu aDepartment of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Rice University, Houston, TX, USA bYahoo! Research, Sunnyvale, California, USA
Abstract

We study the personalized federated learning problem under asynchronous updates. In this problem, each client seeks to obtain a personalized model that simultaneously outperforms local and global models. We consider two optimization-based frameworks for personalization: (i) Model-Agnostic Meta-Learning (MAML) and (ii) Moreau Envelope (ME). MAML involves learning a joint model adapted for each client through fine-tuning, whereas ME requires a bi-level optimization problem with implicit gradients to enforce personalization via regularized losses. We focus on improving the scalability of personalized federated learning by removing the synchronous communication assumption. Moreover, we extend the studied function class by removing boundedness assumptions on the gradient norm. Our main technical contribution is a unified proof for asynchronous federated learning with bounded staleness that we apply to MAML and ME personalization frameworks. For the smooth and non-convex functions class, we show the convergence of our method to a first-order stationary point. We illustrate the performance of our method and its tolerance to staleness through experiments for classification tasks over heterogeneous datasets.

keywords:
Federated Learning; Personalization; Asynchronous Communication; Heterogeneous Data; Distributed Optimization; Staleness.

1 Introduction

Federated Learning (FL) is designed to facilitate distributed training of machine learning models across devices by exploiting the data and computation power available to them [38]. A major benefit of FL is its ability to allow training models on data distributed across multiple devices without centralization. This is particularly beneficial in situations with limited sensitive data [32, 33] where clients are reluctant to share their private data. At the same time, it is known that training over a larger set of data points improves the quality of the obtained model [68]. In such scenarios, FL enjoys the power of collaborative learning without relocating the data from its original source [32]. Nevertheless, FL poses challenges such as data heterogeneity (statistical diversity among clients) [34, 17, 11, 42], fairness [14, 43], privacy [24, 69, 30, 55], unreliable communication [60, 64], and staleness [70, 3, 44, 53].

The common underlying assumption that determines the superiority of FL to individual local training is that the data points of all clients are coming from the same distribution, i.e., homogeneous data across clients. Consequently, FL can improve the quality of empirical loss minimization when data available on each device is limited; otherwise, each client may obtain a proper model without collaboration or communication with others. Therefore, FL111We refer to Federated Learning with no personalization as FL. results in a common global model with better generalization across clients [46] compared to individual training. In heterogeneous data setups where clients hold samples from non-identical data distributions, a common (global) model may perform poorly on the local data points of each client. For instance, consider the next word prediction task on a smart keyboard [28], where each client has a unique writing style or emphasis on the vocabulary domain. In this example, the corresponding mobile application is supposed to suggest a set of words that will likely be selected as the next word in the sentence. This scenario clearly states a case with a heterogeneous data setup with a limited sample on each client’s device. Thus, if each client trains a model independently, without collaboration with the other clients, the model will likely perform poorly on the new data due to sample limitation. Hence, the question arises about what will occur if the clients hold data samples from similar (but not identical) distributions.

In FL with heterogeneous data, an ideal scenario is to learn a globally common model easily adaptable to local data on each client, i.e., model fusion. This approach is known as Personalized Federated Learning (PFL), which strives to exploit both the shared and unshared information from the data of all clients. A solution to the model fusion in PFL is to apply transfer learning [73, 12] (e.g., fine-tuning) on a jointly trained model under FL. Interestingly, the centralized version of this problem has been extensively studied in Meta-Learning [66] and Multi-Task Learning [50], where the goal is to obtain a meta (global) model that with (potentially) minimal adaptation performs well on multiple tasks. Particularly, Model-Agnostic Meta-Learning (MAML) [21, 56] proposes an optimization-based formulation that aims to find an initial meta-model with proper performance after applying one or a few steps of (stochastic) gradient descent. The key property of MAML is its ability to gauge fine-tuning during the learning process. Multiple studies have been conducted on the convergence and generalization of MAML [16, 31, 22, 18, 19, 8] for various problems and setups. Fallah et al. [17] suggest the MAML formulation as a potential solution for PFL, and propose Per-FedAvg algorithm for collaborative learning with MAML personalized cost function. Dinh et al. [13] present pFedMe algorithm for PFL via adopting a different formulation for personalization, namely Moreau Envelopes (ME). The proposed algorithm is a joint bi-level optimization problem with personalized parameters which are regularized to be close to the global model. We will elaborate on these two formulations (MAML & ME) in Section 2. Additionally, several recent works have approached PFL mainly through optimization-based [26, 45, 64, 27, 29, 46, 72, 20, 10, 5, 23], or structure-based [9, 65, 59] techniques.

Scalability to large-scale setups with potentially many clients is another major challenge for FL. The proposed algorithms in this scheme, mostly require synchronous communications between the server and clients [47, 38, 23, 10, 43, 17, 13]. Such constraints impose considerable delays on the learning progress, since increasing the concurrency in synchronous updates decreases the training speed and quality. For example, limited communication bandwidth, computation power, and communication failures incur large delays in the training process. In cross-device FL, devices are naturally prone to update and communicate models under less restrictive rules, whereas clients may apply updates in an asynchronous fashion, i.e., staleness. Hogwild! [52] is one of the first efforts to model asynchrony in distributed setup with delayed updates. Multiple works have studied asynchronous training under different setups and assumptions [1, 49, 6, 53, 44, 4, 15]. Specifically, some recent seminal works have studied the convergence of asynchronous SGD-based methods, and show their convergence under certain assumptions on maximum or average delay [2, 61, 37, 48].222Mishchenko et al. [48] studies the convergence of distributed optimization for homogeneous strongly convex and smooth functions with no assumptions on maximum delay, i.e., unbounded staleness. In decentralized setups, Hadjicostis et al. [25] propose a consensus algorithm called running-sum, which is robust to message losses. Furthermore, Olshevsky et al. [54] present a more general framework with robustness to asynchrony, message losses, and delays for both consensus and optimization problems [60, 64]. More closely, FL under stale updates has been thoroughly studied in [70, 51, 3, 57, 40, 65]. Particularly, Tziotis et al. [65] studies the existence of stragglers in PFL via shared representations, i.e., system and data heterogeneity in structure-based personalization.

The main contribution of paper [51] is on the server algorithm, where this paper proposes a more secure and robust algorithm by aggregating a buffer of asynchronous updates within a secure channel prior to sending them to the server. Whereas, our work focuses on scalability and personalization via asynchronous communication and learning personalized models.

In this work, we study the PFL problem under asynchronous communications to improve training concurrency, performance, and efficiency. We propose the PersA-FL algorithm, a novel personalized & asynchronous method that jointly addresses the heterogeneity and staleness in FL. We develop a technique based on asynchronous updates to resolve the communication bottleneck imposed by synchronized learning in PFL, where we improve the training scalability and performance. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first study on the intersection of staleness and personalization through the lens of optimization-based techniques. We summarize our contributions as follows:

  • •

    Through the integration of two personalization formulations, MAML & ME, we propose PersA-FL, an algorithm that allows personalized federated learning under asynchronous communications between the server and clients. Our proposed method consists of two algorithms from the perspectives of the server and clients. We present the client algorithm under three different options for the local updates, each addressing a separate formulation, (A) FedAsync, (B) PersA-FL-MAML, and (C) PersA-FL-ME.

  • •

    We present a new convergence analysis for Asynchronous Federated Learning (FedAsync) under smooth non-convex cost functions by removing the boundedness assumption from the gradient norm. Our analysis assumes bounded variance of stochasticity and heterogeneity, and bounded maximum delay. Hence, we improve the existing theory by extending the result to a broader function class, i.e., unbounded gradient norm.

  • •

    We show the convergence rate of PersA-FL-MAML based on the maximum delay and personalization budget under the same assumptions as Fallah et al. [17].333Besides the assumptions for FedAsync, seminal works [17, 22, 56] assume second-order Lipschitzness, bounded variance, and bounded gradient in the analysis of MAML cost functions. We highlight the impact of batch size in the biased stochastic estimation of the full gradients for the MAML cost. We present the communication and sample complexity to find an ε𝜀\varepsilon first-order stationary point for the proposed algorithm.

  • •

    We prove the convergence of PersA-FL-ME with no boundedness assumption on the gradient norm. We discuss the connection of convergence rate to the gradient estimation error and level of personalization. Compared to [13], we show an explicit dependence of convergence rate to the estimation error. Moreover, we relax the heterogeneity assumption in [13] allowing bounded population diversity instead of uniformly bounded heterogeneity. We determine the communication and local inexact solver complexity to find an ε𝜀\varepsilon first-order stationary point for this method.

  • •

    We present numerical experiments evaluating our proposed algorithm on heterogeneous MNIST and CIFAR10 with unbalanced distributions across the clients. We illustrate the advantages of our method in terms of performance and scalability to varying delays in setups with heterogeneity.

Table 1 illustrates the properties of our proposed method and provides a comparison between our algorithm and underlying analysis with related seminal works. As shown in this table, building upon the results in [17, 13], we extend the capability of FL to staleness. Table 1 also contains the convergence results for our proposed algorithm, which we will discuss in more details in Section 4.

The main difference between our method and the works in [70, 51] mainly lies in the client algorithm, where we consider three options (A, B, and C) for updating the parameters locally. Option A is similar to the client algorithm in [70, 51], but we improve the theoretical convergence results by removing the assumption on bounded gradients for this setup. Option B and Option C, along with the server algorithm are novel methods for personalized asynchronous federated learning. Nguyen et al. [51] characterize the server algorithm with a secure and robust update aggregation and [63] enhances its theoretical properties. Study of secure aggregation on the server side remains as a future direction for this work.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. In Section 2, we introduce the PFL setup and discuss the asynchronous communication framework between the server and clients. In Section 3, we describe our algorithm, PersA-FL, for PFL under staleness. In Section 4, we state the convergence result for our proposed algorithm along with the underlying assumptions and technical lemmas. We present the numerical experiments in Section 5. We finally end by concluding remarks in Section 6.

2 Problem Setup & Background

In this section, we first present the formal problem setup for FL [47], as well as the personalization formulations in MAML [17] and ME [13]. Then, we discuss the underlying communication setting under asynchronous updates.

2.1 Federated Learning Problem Setup

We consider a set of n𝑛n clients and one server, where each client i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n] holds a private function fi:ℝd→ℝ:subscript𝑓𝑖→superscriptℝ𝑑ℝf_{i}:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}, and the goal is to collaboratively obtain a model w∈ℝd𝑤superscriptℝ𝑑w\in\mathbb{R}^{d} that minimizes the local cost functions on average, as follows:

where ℓi:ℝd×𝒮i→ℝ:subscriptℓ𝑖→superscriptℝ𝑑subscript𝒮𝑖ℝ\ell_{i}:\mathbb{R}^{d}\times\mathcal{S}_{i}\to\mathbb{R} is a cost function that determines the prediction error of some model w∈ℝd𝑤superscriptℝ𝑑w\in\mathbb{R}^{d} over a single data point ξi∈𝒮isubscript𝜉𝑖subscript𝒮𝑖\xi_{i}\in\mathcal{S}_{i} on client i𝑖i, where ξisubscript𝜉𝑖\xi_{i} is a realization of Ξi∼pisimilar-tosubscriptΞ𝑖subscript𝑝𝑖\Xi_{i}\sim p_{i}, i.e., pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i} is the client i𝑖i’s data distribution over 𝒮isubscript𝒮𝑖\mathcal{S}_{i}, for i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n]. For instance, in a supervised learning setup with 𝒵i≔𝒳i×𝒴i≔subscript𝒵𝑖subscript𝒳𝑖subscript𝒴𝑖\mathcal{Z}_{i}\coloneqq\mathcal{X}_{i}\times\mathcal{Y}_{i}, we have ℓi​(w,ξi)subscriptℓ𝑖𝑤subscript𝜉𝑖\ell_{i}(w,\xi_{i}) as the prediction cost of some learning model parameterized by w𝑤w for sample ξi=(x,y)subscript𝜉𝑖𝑥𝑦\xi_{i}=(x,y), where x∈𝒳i𝑥subscript𝒳𝑖x\in\mathcal{X}_{i} and y∈𝒴i𝑦subscript𝒴𝑖y\in\mathcal{Y}_{i}. Let 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i} be a data batch with samples independently drawn from the distribution pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i}. Then, the unbiased stochastic cost associated with data batch 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i} can be denoted as follows:

where for simplicity, we assume that the size of all batches is larger than b𝑏b. Then, according to the above definition, we can immediately infer that

𝔼pi​[f~i​(w,𝒟i)]=fi​(w),𝔼pi​[∇f~i​(w,𝒟i)]=∇fi​(w),𝔼pi​[∇2f~i​(w,𝒟i)]=∇2fi​(w).formulae-sequencesubscript𝔼subscript𝑝𝑖delimited-[]subscript~𝑓𝑖𝑤subscript𝒟𝑖subscript𝑓𝑖𝑤formulae-sequencesubscript𝔼subscript𝑝𝑖delimited-[]∇subscript~𝑓𝑖𝑤subscript𝒟𝑖∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝑤subscript𝔼subscript𝑝𝑖delimited-[]superscript∇2subscript~𝑓𝑖𝑤subscript𝒟𝑖superscript∇2subscript𝑓𝑖𝑤\displaystyle\begin{split}\mathbb{E}_{p_{i}}\left[\tilde{f}_{i}(w,\mathcal{D}_{i})\right]&=f_{i}(w),\\ \mathbb{E}_{p_{i}}\left[\nabla\tilde{f}_{i}(w,\mathcal{D}_{i})\right]&=\nabla f_{i}(w),\\ \mathbb{E}_{p_{i}}\left[\nabla^{2}\tilde{f}_{i}(w,\mathcal{D}_{i})\right]&=\nabla^{2}f_{i}(w).\end{split} (3)

Several works have been proposed to solve (1) as a union of local and global optimization steps. For instance, FedAvg [47] suggests an iterative algorithm wherein at each round t≥0𝑡0t\geq 0, (i) server transmits its current parameter wtsuperscript𝑤𝑡w^{t} to a subset of the clients, (ii) each selected client updates the parameter locally, by applying Q𝑄Q sequential rounds of stochastic gradient descent (SGD) with respect to its local cost function, then (iii) the selected clients send back their local parameter to the server, and finally, (iv) the server aggregates the so-called local parameters to obtain a new global parameter wt+1superscript𝑤𝑡1w^{t+1}. As a result, clients minimize the average loss in (1) with less communication cost, i.e., fewer global rounds. Note that the underlying assumption for methods such as FedAvg is the possibility of synchronized communications between the selected clients and the server. The left chart in Figure 1 represents the communication and update schedule for FedAvg. The performance of FL-based methods depends on the similarity of distributions 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i}, thus, cases with heterogeneous datasets slow down the convergence. Karimireddy et al. [34] and [11] the effect of heterogeneity in the convergence speed. A solution of (1) is a common model for all the clients; hence no adaptation or fusion to each client’s data. Next, we elaborate on the personalization concept and discuss two alternative problem formulations for (1).

2.2 Personalized Federated Learning

In the previous section, we explained how a solution to (1) performs well when the data is homogeneous, and the goal is to obtain a shared model. On the one hand, using a single common model, with no adaptation to each client, does not necessarily lead to a proper performance when dealing with heterogeneous datasets. On the other hand, when the data distributions of different clients share some similarities, e.g., bounded variance in their heterogeneity, and the number of data points on each client is limited, joint training with fusion improves the performance compared to individual locally trained models or FL. Therefore, learning a shared model with little fine-tuning, e.g., a few steps of SGD with respect to the local cost, may result in a proper personalized model.

Fallah et al. [17] proposed Per-FedAvg algorithm, which modifies the training loss function by taking advantage of the fact that fine-tuning will occur after training. The MAML formulation assumes a limited computational budget for personalization (fine-tuning) at each client. It then offers to look for an initial (global) parameter that performs well after it is updated with one or a few steps of SGD. In other words, [17] define the MAML loss function for PFL as follows:

minw∈ℝd⁡F(b)​(w)≔1n​∑i=1nFi(b)​(w),withFi(b)​(w)≔fi​(w−α​∇fi​(w)),formulae-sequence≔subscript𝑤superscriptℝ𝑑superscript𝐹𝑏𝑤1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝐹𝑏𝑖𝑤with≔subscriptsuperscript𝐹𝑏𝑖𝑤subscript𝑓𝑖𝑤𝛼∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝑤\displaystyle\begin{split}\min_{w\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}F^{(b)}(w)&\coloneqq\frac{1}{n}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}F^{(b)}_{i}(w),\\ \text{with}\quad F^{(b)}_{i}(w)&\coloneqq f_{i}(w-\alpha\nabla f_{i}(w)),\end{split} (4)

where α≥0𝛼0\alpha\geq 0 is the MAML personalization stepsize. Solving (4) yields a global (meta) model that can be used to create a personalized model by applying one step of gradient descent with respect to individual loss functions. The degree of fine-tuning determines the personalization budget, which often controls the trade-off between having a local (personalized) or generic model, i.e., exploiting the shared and local knowledge simultaneously. In Problem (4), stepsize α𝛼\alpha determines the personalization budget, where α=0𝛼0\alpha=0 implies FL in Problem (1). See [31, 64, 18] for the study of multi-step MAML. In a nutshell, Per-FedAvg proposes to minimize F(b)​(w)superscript𝐹𝑏𝑤F^{(b)}(w) via a similar paradigm as FedAvg. Hence, each client i𝑖i computes the personalized gradient of its MAML cost in (4), which can be written as follows:

∇Fi(b)​(w)=[I−α​∇2fi​(w)]​∇fi​(w−α​∇fi​(w)),∇subscriptsuperscript𝐹𝑏𝑖𝑤delimited-[]𝐼𝛼superscript∇2subscript𝑓𝑖𝑤∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝑤𝛼∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝑤\displaystyle\nabla F^{(b)}_{i}(w)=\left[I{-}\alpha\nabla^{2}f_{i}(w)\right]\nabla f_{i}\left(w{-}\alpha\nabla f_{i}(w)\right), (5)

where in Per-FedAvg, the authors propose to compute a biased estimation of (5) using stochastic gradients/Hessian. We will elaborate on the stochastic approximation in Section 3.

On a separate note, one of the major challenges in Per-FedAvg is the computation of second-order information such as Hessian for large-scale models (large d𝑑d). However, as proposed by [17], one can skip the Hessian in the gradient formulation (FO-MAML) or approximate it with first-order information (HF-MAML) [16].

As an alternative option to MAML formulation in (4), Dinh et al. [13] suggest solving the following optimization problem:

minw∈ℝd⁡F(c)​(w)≔1n​∑i=1nFi(c)​(w),withFi(c)​(w)≔minθi∈ℝd⁡[fi​(θi)+λ2​‖θi−w‖2],formulae-sequence≔subscript𝑤superscriptℝ𝑑superscript𝐹𝑐𝑤1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝐹𝑐𝑖𝑤with≔subscriptsuperscript𝐹𝑐𝑖𝑤subscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖superscriptℝ𝑑subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝜃𝑖𝜆2superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝜃𝑖𝑤2\displaystyle\begin{split}\min_{w\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}F^{(c)}(w)&\coloneqq\frac{1}{n}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}F^{(c)}_{i}(w),\\ \text{with}\quad F^{(c)}_{i}(w)&\coloneqq\min_{\theta_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}\left[f_{i}(\theta_{i})+\frac{\lambda}{2}{\left\|\theta_{i}-w\right\|}^{2}\right],\end{split} (6)

where each function Fi(c)​(w)subscriptsuperscript𝐹𝑐𝑖𝑤F^{(c)}_{i}(w) is a local cost of personalized parameter θi∈ℝdsubscript𝜃𝑖superscriptℝ𝑑\theta_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} by using the Moreau Envelope as a regularized loss function, and parameter λ≥0𝜆0\lambda\geq 0 determines the degree of personalization. In this setup, λ=0𝜆0\lambda=0 is equivalent to local training with no collaboration and as λ→∞→𝜆\lambda\to\infty, the formulation in (6) converges to FL in (1) with no personalization which is similar to the case in (4) with α=0𝛼0\alpha=0. For non-extreme values of λ𝜆\lambda, the clients jointly learn a global model w𝑤w and personalized parameters θisubscript𝜃𝑖\theta_{i}, which are regularized to remain close to w𝑤w. Note that the gradient of Fi(c)​(w)subscriptsuperscript𝐹𝑐𝑖𝑤F^{(c)}_{i}(w) can be written as follows (please check out Appendix C to see the proof):

∇Fi(c)​(w)∇subscriptsuperscript𝐹𝑐𝑖𝑤\displaystyle\nabla F^{(c)}_{i}(w) =λ​(w−θ^i​(w)),absent𝜆𝑤subscript^𝜃𝑖𝑤\displaystyle=\lambda\left(w-\hat{\theta}_{i}(w)\right), (7)
withθ^i​(w)≔≔withsubscript^𝜃𝑖𝑤absent\displaystyle\text{with}\quad\hat{\theta}_{i}(w)\coloneqq arg​minθi∈ℝd⁡[fi​(θi)+λ2​‖θi−w‖2],subscriptargminsubscript𝜃𝑖superscriptℝ𝑑subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝜃𝑖𝜆2superscriptnormsubscript𝜃𝑖𝑤2\displaystyle\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\theta_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}\left[f_{i}(\theta_{i})+\frac{\lambda}{2}{\left\|\theta_{i}-w\right\|}^{2}\right], (8)

where for large λ𝜆\lambda, θ^i​(w)subscript^𝜃𝑖𝑤\hat{\theta}_{i}(w) is the exact solution to an optimization problem. Therefore, solving (6) through a similar approach to FedAvg or Per-FedAvg, itself requires minimizing Problem (8) which is potentially intractable. Dinh et al. [13] propose a bi-level optimization algorithm called pFedMe, to minimize the optimization problem in (6) by alternating minimization over θisubscript𝜃𝑖\theta_{i} and w𝑤w. The main idea behind pFedMe is to integrating the computation of an inexact solution to (8) inside an FL-type method. We will explain and use this inexact approximation in the presentation of our method (Option C) in Section 3.

2.3 Asynchronous vs Synchronous Schedule

So far, we have discussed the three different formulations for collaborative learning that we will consider in our method. As we described the FedAvg algorithm in Subsection 2.1, at each round t𝑡t, the parameter wtsuperscript𝑤𝑡w^{t}, which is the most recent version of the global parameter in the server, will be sent to a subset of the clients. Then, the server halts the training process until all selected clients receive this parameter, perform local updates, and transmit their updates back to the server. This synchronization procedure restricts the algorithm flow to the slowest client at each round. Nevertheless, asynchronous updates and communications can be described in this described framework.

Let us provide a comparison using the example in Figure 1 which illustrates the communication and update schedule for synchronous (left) & asynchronous (right) aggregations for n=5𝑛5n=5 clients in FL with Q=3𝑄3Q=3 local updates. As shown in this Figure, for every update at the server-lever under synchronized updates (left figure), the server has to wait for all the selected clients. Nevertheless, these clients build their local updates based on the recent version of the server’s parameter. On the contrary, in the asynchronous scenario (right figure), the server updates the global parameter once it receives a new update from some client. The main challenge for the asynchronous setup is the staleness between download and upload time from/to the server. We design PersA-FL based on the second communication scenario.

3 Algorithm: FedAsync & PersA-FL

In this section, by integrating the problem formulations in (1), (4), and (6) into a united format, we propose Algorithms 1 & 2 to solve these problems under three different update choices at the client-level. We present our method through two different perspectives, (i) server and (ii) client.

⋄⋄\diamond Server Algorithm: Let us denote w0∈ℝdsuperscript𝑤0superscriptℝ𝑑w^{0}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} as the initial parameter at the server, where the objective is to minimize the cost function in either (1), (4), or (6). Each client i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n] may communicate with the server when the underlying connection is stable. Clients may request to download the server’s parameters at any time, and the server will send the most recent model after receiving the request. All underlying delays for the communications between the server and clients are modeled as download and upload delays. We consider variable t𝑡t as a counter for the updates at the server level. Algorithm 1 represents the server updates in PersA-FL. The server performs an iterative algorithm where at each round t≥0𝑡0t\geq 0, remains on hold until receives an update Δit∈ℝdsubscriptΔsubscript𝑖𝑡superscriptℝ𝑑\Delta_{i_{t}}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} from some client it∈[n]subscript𝑖𝑡delimited-[]𝑛i_{t}\in[n]. After receiving the update from client itsubscript𝑖𝑡i_{t}, the server updates its parameter according to Step 4 of Algorithm 1, where β≥0𝛽0\beta\geq 0 is the server stepsize.

Now, we are ready to present the client algorithm. Before starting, note that we drop the time index from the iterates of the client algorithm for clarity of exposition.

⋄⋄\diamond Client Algorithm: Let us explain the operations of i𝑖i-th client using the pseudo code in Algorithm 2. Client i𝑖i repeats an iterative procedure which is composed of three phases, (i) downloading the most up-to-date model from the server as in Step 3, (ii) performing Q𝑄Q local updates starting from the parameters of the downloaded model with respect to the cost function of the underlying problem, (1), (4), or (6), as in Steps 5-16, and (iii) uploading the sum of updates on the server as in Step 18. Note that η≥0𝜂0\eta\geq 0 is the local stepsize, a hyperparameter. The main idea for the local updates is to perform Q𝑄Q sequential SGD steps on the local cost. Below, we list our stochastic estimation for the full gradients of each loss function introduced in Section 2:

  • •

    Option A: This option intends to minimize (1). Therefore, for each client i𝑖i at each local round q𝑞q, we sample an independent data batch from pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i} and compute an unbiased estimation of the loss as in (2).

  • •

    Option B: By performing this option, we aim to minimize the MAML cost function in (4). As we saw in Section 2, the full gradient can be computed according to (5). Following [17], we sample three data batches to compute a biased estimation of (5) as follows:

    ∇F~i(b)​(w,𝒟i′′,𝒟i′,𝒟i)=[I−α​∇2f~i​(w,𝒟i′′)]​∇f~i​(w−α​∇f~i​(w,𝒟i′),𝒟i).∇subscriptsuperscript~𝐹𝑏𝑖𝑤superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑖′′superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑖′subscript𝒟𝑖delimited-[]𝐼𝛼superscript∇2subscript~𝑓𝑖𝑤superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑖′′∇subscript~𝑓𝑖𝑤𝛼∇subscript~𝑓𝑖𝑤superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑖′subscript𝒟𝑖\displaystyle\nabla\tilde{F}^{(b)}_{i}(w,\mathcal{D}_{i}^{\prime\prime},\mathcal{D}_{i}^{\prime},\mathcal{D}_{i})=\left[I{-}\alpha\nabla^{2}\tilde{f}_{i}(w,\mathcal{D}_{i}^{\prime\prime})\right]\nabla\tilde{f}_{i}\left(w{-}\alpha\nabla\tilde{f}_{i}(w,\mathcal{D}_{i}^{\prime}),\mathcal{D}_{i}\right). (9)

    We will discuss the variance and bias of this estimator in Subsection 4.2

  • •

    Option C: Finally, we invoke this option to minimize the ME personalized loss in (6). As we mentioned earlier, the full gradient of this cost is (7), where for a fixed w𝑤w, we may obtain θ^i​(w)subscript^𝜃𝑖𝑤\hat{\theta}_{i}(w) by minimizing (8). Instead, following [13], we define the stochastic approximation h~i​(θi,w,𝒟i)subscript~ℎ𝑖subscript𝜃𝑖𝑤subscript𝒟𝑖\tilde{h}_{i}(\theta_{i},w,\mathcal{D}_{i}) as in Step 14, and minimize this function with respect to θisubscript𝜃𝑖\theta_{i} to obtain an approximate solution θ~i​(w)subscript~𝜃𝑖𝑤\tilde{\theta}_{i}(w) where the gradient’s norm is less than some threshold ν≥0𝜈0\nu\geq 0. Therefore, we approximate (7) with the following estimator:

    ∇F~i(c)​(w,𝒟i)=λ​(w−θ~i​(w)).∇subscriptsuperscript~𝐹𝑐𝑖𝑤subscript𝒟𝑖𝜆𝑤subscript~𝜃𝑖𝑤\displaystyle\nabla\tilde{F}^{(c)}_{i}(w,\mathcal{D}_{i})=\lambda\left(w-\tilde{\theta}_{i}(w)\right). (10)

    Let us denote the expectation of h~i(.)\tilde{h}_{i}(.) as hi(.)h_{i}(.). Then, for λ>L𝜆𝐿\lambda>L, the expected function is (λ+L)𝜆𝐿(\lambda{+}L)-smooth and (λ−L)𝜆𝐿(\lambda{-}L)-strongly convex due to the properties of Moreau Envelopes [13]. Then according to the property of [7, 13], for some ν≤1𝜈1\nu\leq 1 (e.g., 10−5superscript10510^{{-}5}), we can find θ~i​(w)subscript~𝜃𝑖𝑤\tilde{\theta}_{i}(w) in 𝒪​(λ+Lλ−L​log⁡(1ν))𝒪𝜆𝐿𝜆𝐿1𝜈\mathcal{O}(\frac{\lambda{+}L}{\lambda{-}L}\log(\frac{1}{\nu})) iterations.

    We will also discuss the properties of (10) in Subsection 4.3.

Next, we present the convergence result of our method for the three formulations.

4 Convergence Results

In this section, we introduce the technical theorems and lemmas to show the convergence of our method for the three described scenarios. First, we introduce the common assumptions we will use in our analysis for all the three choices of Algorithm 2. As mentioned earlier, we require some additional assumptions to show the convergence of MAML, which we will introduce in Subsection 4.2. After stating the assumptions, we will present the convergence results.

Recall that the server updates its model at round t𝑡t using the updates sent by client it∈[n]subscript𝑖𝑡delimited-[]𝑛i_{t}\in[n]. We denote Ω​(t)Ω𝑡\Omega(t) as the timestep of the round at which client itsubscript𝑖𝑡i_{t} has received the server’s parameters before applying its Q𝑄Q local updates. In other words, (Ω​(t),t)Ω𝑡𝑡(\Omega(t),t) denote the download and upload rounds for client itsubscript𝑖𝑡i_{t}. Now, we introduce the assumption of maximum delay.

Assumption 1 (Bounded Staleness).

For all server steps t≥0𝑡0t\geq 0, the staleness or effective delay between the model version at the download step Ω​(t)Ω𝑡\Omega(t) and upload step t𝑡t is bounded by some constant τ𝜏\tau, i.e.,

supt≥0|t−Ω​(t)|≤τ,subscriptsupremum𝑡0𝑡Ω𝑡𝜏\displaystyle\sup_{t\geq 0}\left|t-\Omega(t)\right|\leq\tau, (11)

and the server receives updates uniformly, i.e., it∼Uniform​([n])similar-tosubscript𝑖𝑡Uniformdelimited-[]𝑛i_{t}\sim\mathrm{Uniform}([n]).

The above assumption is standard in the analysis of asynchronous methods, specifically in heterogeneous settings [51, 70, 3, 37, 61, 2]. Assumption 1 guarantees that all clients remain active over the course of training. However, they have transient delays and perform updates with staleness.

Next, we present our only assumption on the function class, i.e., smooth non-convex.

Assumption 2 (Smoothness).

For all clients i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n], function fi:ℝd→ℝ:subscript𝑓𝑖→superscriptℝ𝑑ℝf_{i}:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R} is bounded below, differentiable, and L𝐿L-smooth, i.e., for all w,u∈ℝd𝑤𝑢superscriptℝ𝑑w,u\in\mathbb{R}^{d},

∥∇fi​(w)−∇fi​(u)∥≤L​∥w−u∥delimited-∥∥∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝑤∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝑢𝐿delimited-∥∥𝑤𝑢\displaystyle\left\lVert\nabla f_{i}(w)-\nabla f_{i}(u)\right\rVert\leq L\lVert w-u\rVert (12)
fi⋆≔minw∈ℝd⁡fi​(w)>−∞.≔superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖⋆subscript𝑤superscriptℝ𝑑subscript𝑓𝑖𝑤\displaystyle f_{i}^{\star}\coloneqq\min_{w\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}f_{i}(w)>-\infty. (13)

The smoothness assumption is conventional in the analysis of non-convex functions. We also assume boundedness from below, which is reasonable since the ultimate goal is to minimize the functions. We also denote f⋆=mini∈[n]⁡fi⋆superscript𝑓⋆subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖⋆f^{\star}=\min_{i\in[n]}f_{i}^{\star}, where according to this definition, we can immediately see that f⋆≤minw∈ℝd⁡F(b)​(w)superscript𝑓⋆subscript𝑤superscriptℝ𝑑superscript𝐹𝑏𝑤f^{\star}\leq\min_{w\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}F^{(b)}(w) and f⋆≤minw∈ℝd⁡F(c)​(w)superscript𝑓⋆subscript𝑤superscriptℝ𝑑superscript𝐹𝑐𝑤f^{\star}\leq\min_{w\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}F^{(c)}(w).

Now, we present our assumptions on bounded stochasticity and heterogeneity.

Assumption 3 (Bounded Variance).

For all clients i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n], the variance of a stochastic gradient ∇ℓi​(w,ξi)∇subscriptℓ𝑖𝑤subscript𝜉𝑖\nabla\ell_{i}(w,\xi_{i}) on a single data point ξi∈𝒮isubscript𝜉𝑖subscript𝒮𝑖\xi_{i}\in\mathcal{S}_{i} is bounded, i.e., for all w∈ℝd𝑤superscriptℝ𝑑w\in\mathbb{R}^{d}

𝔼ξi∼pi​∥∇ℓi​(w,ξi)−∇fi​(w)∥2≤σg2.subscript𝔼similar-tosubscript𝜉𝑖subscript𝑝𝑖superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇subscriptℓ𝑖𝑤subscript𝜉𝑖∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝑤2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑔2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{\xi_{i}\sim p_{i}}\left\lVert\nabla\ell_{i}(w,\xi_{i})-\nabla f_{i}(w)\right\rVert^{2}\leq\sigma_{g}^{2}. (14)

Assumption 3 is standard in the analysis of SGD-based methods and has been used in many relevant works [62, 51, 35, 67, 36, 37, 64]. Since we perform updates using data batches, we also need to show the stochastic variance for the sampled batches. Recall that for simplicity; we assumed that all batch sizes are larger than b≥1𝑏1b\geq 1, thus, we have:

𝔼pi​∥∇f~i​(w,𝒟i)−∇fi​(w)∥2≤σg2|𝒟i|≤σa2≔σg2bsubscript𝔼subscript𝑝𝑖superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇subscript~𝑓𝑖𝑤subscript𝒟𝑖∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝑤2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑔2subscript𝒟𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑎2≔superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑔2𝑏\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{p_{i}}\left\lVert\nabla\tilde{f}_{i}(w,\mathcal{D}_{i})-\nabla f_{i}(w)\right\rVert^{2}\leq\frac{\sigma_{g}^{2}}{|\mathcal{D}_{i}|}\leq\sigma_{a}^{2}\coloneqq\frac{\sigma_{g}^{2}}{b} (15)

Next, we present the bounded heterogeneity assumption.

Assumption 4 (Bounded Population Diversity).

For all w∈ℝd𝑤superscriptℝ𝑑w\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, the gradients of local functions fi​(w)subscript𝑓𝑖𝑤f_{i}(w) and the global function f​(w)𝑓𝑤f(w) satisfy the following property:

1n​∑i=1n∥∇fi​(w)−∇f​(w)∥2≤γg2.1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝑤∇𝑓𝑤2superscriptsubscript𝛾𝑔2\displaystyle\frac{1}{n}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}\lVert\nabla f_{i}(w)-\nabla f(w)\rVert^{2}\leq\gamma_{g}^{2}. (16)

The above assumption measures the population diversity (heterogeneity) between the gradients. In heterogeneous settings, this bound indicates the similarity between different distributions. Fallah et al. [17] show connections between heterogeneity and the Wasserstein distance between the distributions under certain assumptions.

The above assumptions are sufficient to prove the convergence of our method (Algorithms 1 & 2) under Option A and Option C. Therefore, we present the convergence analyses starting from our results on FedAsync.

4.1 Asynchronous Federated Learning (Option A)

We now demonstrate the convergence rate of our method for the cost function in (1).

Theorem 1 (FedAsync).

Let Assumptions 1-4 hold, β=1𝛽1\beta=1, and η=1Q​L​T𝜂1𝑄𝐿𝑇\eta=\frac{1}{Q\sqrt{LT}}. Then, the following property holds for the joint iterates of Algorithms 1 & 2 under Option A on Problem (1): for any timestep T≥160​L​(Q+7)​(τ+1)3𝑇160𝐿𝑄7superscript𝜏13T\geq 160L(Q{+}7)(\tau{+}1)^{3} at the server

1T​∑t=0T−1𝔼​∥∇f​(wt)∥21𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇1𝔼superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝑓superscript𝑤𝑡2\displaystyle\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\,\mathbb{E}\left\lVert\nabla f\left(w^{t}\right)\right\rVert^{2} ≤4​L​(f​(w0)−f⋆)T+8​L​(σg2b+γg2)Tabsent4𝐿𝑓superscript𝑤0superscript𝑓⋆𝑇8𝐿superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑔2𝑏superscriptsubscript𝛾𝑔2𝑇\displaystyle\leq\frac{4\sqrt{L}\left(f(w^{0})-f^{\star}\right)}{\sqrt{T}}+\frac{8\sqrt{L}\left(\frac{\sigma_{g}^{2}}{b}+\gamma_{g}^{2}\right)}{\sqrt{T}}
+80​L​(1+Q)​(τ2+1)​(σg2b+γg2)T.80𝐿1𝑄superscript𝜏21superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑔2𝑏superscriptsubscript𝛾𝑔2𝑇\displaystyle+\frac{80L(1{+}Q)(\tau^{2}{+}1)\left(\frac{\sigma_{g}^{2}}{b}+\gamma_{g}^{2}\right)}{T}.

The proof of Theorem 1 is provided in Appendix A. This theorem suggests a convergence rate of 𝒪​(1T)+𝒪​(Q​τ2T)𝒪1𝑇𝒪𝑄superscript𝜏2𝑇\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{T}}\right)+\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{Q\tau^{2}}{T}\right) for asynchronous federated learning FedAsync. Our analysis removes the unnecessary boundedness assumption on the gradient norm.

Remark 1.

Selecting β=1𝛽1\beta=1 in Theorem 1, results in a sub-optimal first-order stationary rate for smooth non-convex cost functions. However, this is an arbitrary choice for the value of β𝛽\beta and can be relaxed to any β=𝒪​(1)𝛽𝒪1\beta=\mathcal{O}(1) similar to [51].

Next, we present the convergence of PersA-FL-MAML along with some technical lemmas borrowed from [17].

4.2 Personalized Asynchronous Federated Learning: Model-Agnostic Meta-Learning Setup (Option B)

As we discussed in Section 3, we require the second-order derivatives of the local functions to compute the gradients of the personalized costs in (4). Accordingly, we consider similar assumptions for the second-order derivatives as Assumptions 2-4.

Assumption 5 (Second-Order Properties).

For all clients i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n], the following properties hold for the Hessian of each fi:ℝd→ℝ:subscript𝑓𝑖→superscriptℝ𝑑ℝf_{i}:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}, the variance of a stochastic Hessian ∇2ℓi​(w,ξi)superscript∇2subscriptℓ𝑖𝑤subscript𝜉𝑖\nabla^{2}\ell_{i}(w,\xi_{i}) on a single data point ξi∈𝒮isubscript𝜉𝑖subscript𝒮𝑖\xi_{i}\in\mathcal{S}_{i}, and the global Hessian ∇2f​(w)superscript∇2𝑓𝑤\nabla^{2}f(w): for all w,u∈ℝd𝑤𝑢superscriptℝ𝑑w,u\in\mathbb{R}^{d},

∥∇2fi​(w)−∇2fi​(u)∥≤ρ​∥w−u∥,delimited-∥∥superscript∇2subscript𝑓𝑖𝑤superscript∇2subscript𝑓𝑖𝑢𝜌delimited-∥∥𝑤𝑢\displaystyle\left\lVert\nabla^{2}f_{i}(w)-\nabla^{2}f_{i}(u)\right\rVert\leq\rho\lVert w-u\rVert, (17)
𝔼ξi∼pisubscript𝔼similar-tosubscript𝜉𝑖subscript𝑝𝑖\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{\xi_{i}\sim p_{i}} ∥∇2ℓi​(w,ξi)−∇2fi​(w)∥2≤σh2,superscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript∇2subscriptℓ𝑖𝑤subscript𝜉𝑖superscript∇2subscript𝑓𝑖𝑤2superscriptsubscript𝜎ℎ2\displaystyle\left\lVert\nabla^{2}\ell_{i}(w,\xi_{i})-\nabla^{2}f_{i}(w)\right\rVert^{2}\leq\sigma_{h}^{2}, (18)
1n​∑i=1n1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛\displaystyle\frac{1}{n}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n} ∥∇2fi​(w)−∇2f​(w)∥2≤γh2.superscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript∇2subscript𝑓𝑖𝑤superscript∇2𝑓𝑤2superscriptsubscript𝛾ℎ2\displaystyle\left\lVert\nabla^{2}f_{i}(w)-\nabla^{2}f(w)\right\rVert^{2}\leq\gamma_{h}^{2}. (19)

Assumption 5 is conventional in the analysis of methods with access to second-order information [16, 17, 58, 64]. Finally, we adopt another assumption from [22, 17, 19] on the gradient norm to simplify the analysis for the MAML cost.

Assumption 6 (Bounded-Gradient).

There exists a constant G𝐺G such that for all clients i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n], and any parameter w∈ℝd𝑤superscriptℝ𝑑w\in\mathbb{R}^{d},

∥∇fi​(w)∥≤G.delimited-∥∥∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝑤𝐺\displaystyle\left\lVert\nabla f_{i}(w)\right\rVert\leq G. (20)

To the best of our knowledge, seminal works on MAML loss mainly consider this assumption to simplify the properties of the personalized function. Note that we consider Assumptions 5-6 only in the analysis of PersA-FL (Algorithms 1 & 2) under Option B. Under Assumptions 2 and 6, the properties in (19) and (16) can be simply derived with γh=2​Lsubscript𝛾ℎ2𝐿\gamma_{h}=2L and γg=2​Gsubscript𝛾𝑔2𝐺\gamma_{g}=2G [17].

Before stating the convergence of PersA-FL-MAML, let us state some technical lemmas on the personalized MAML cost function.

Lemma 1 ([17], Lemma 4.2 - Smoothness: MAML).

Let Assumptions 2 and 6 hold. Then, Fi(b)subscriptsuperscript𝐹𝑏𝑖F^{(b)}_{i} in (4) is Lbsubscript𝐿𝑏L_{b}-smooth, i.e., for all clients i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n], and any parameters w,u∈ℝd𝑤𝑢superscriptℝ𝑑w,u\in\mathbb{R}^{d},

∥∇Fi(b)​(w)−∇Fi(b)​(u)∥≤Lb​∥w−u∥,delimited-∥∥∇subscriptsuperscript𝐹𝑏𝑖𝑤∇subscriptsuperscript𝐹𝑏𝑖𝑢subscript𝐿𝑏delimited-∥∥𝑤𝑢\displaystyle\left\lVert\nabla F^{(b)}_{i}(w)-\nabla F^{(b)}_{i}(u)\right\rVert\leq L_{b}\lVert w-u\rVert, (21)

where Lb≔L​(1+α​L)2+α​ρ​G≔subscript𝐿𝑏𝐿superscript1𝛼𝐿2𝛼𝜌𝐺L_{b}\coloneqq L(1{+}\alpha L)^{2}+\alpha\rho G.

Lemma 1 indicates that the personalized cost in (4) is also smooth. The smoothness parameter Lbsubscript𝐿𝑏L_{b} depends on the personalization hyperparameter α𝛼\alpha. Increasing the value of α𝛼\alpha results in higher smoothness constant Lbsubscript𝐿𝑏L_{b}. The smoothness property of MAML cost under multi-step personalization (instead of one) is shown in [64][Lemma 3].

Lemma 2 ([17], Lemma 4.3 - Bounded Variance: MAML).

Let Assumptions 2, 3, 5, and 6 hold, and data batches 𝒟,𝒟′,𝒟′′𝒟superscript𝒟′superscript𝒟′′\mathcal{D},\mathcal{D}^{\prime},\mathcal{D}^{\prime\prime} be randomly sampled according to data distribution pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i}. Then, the following properties hold for the stochastic personalized gradient ∇F~i(b)​(w,𝒟′′,𝒟′,𝒟)∇subscriptsuperscript~𝐹𝑏𝑖𝑤superscript𝒟′′superscript𝒟′𝒟\nabla\tilde{F}^{(b)}_{i}(w,\mathcal{D}^{\prime\prime},\mathcal{D}^{\prime},\mathcal{D}):

∥𝔼pi​[∇F~i(b)​(w,𝒟′′,𝒟′,𝒟)−∇Fi(b)​(w)]∥delimited-∥∥subscript𝔼subscript𝑝𝑖delimited-[]∇subscriptsuperscript~𝐹𝑏𝑖𝑤superscript𝒟′′superscript𝒟′𝒟∇subscriptsuperscript𝐹𝑏𝑖𝑤\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbb{E}_{p_{i}}\left[\nabla\tilde{F}^{(b)}_{i}(w,\mathcal{D}^{\prime\prime},\mathcal{D}^{\prime},\mathcal{D})-\nabla F^{(b)}_{i}(w)\right]\right\rVert ≤μb≔α​L​(1+α​L)​σgb,absentsubscript𝜇𝑏≔𝛼𝐿1𝛼𝐿subscript𝜎𝑔𝑏\displaystyle\leq\mu_{b}\coloneqq\frac{\alpha L(1{+}\alpha L)\sigma_{g}}{\sqrt{b}}, (22)
𝔼pi​∥∇F~i(b)​(w,𝒟′′,𝒟′,𝒟)−∇Fi(b)​(w)∥2subscript𝔼subscript𝑝𝑖superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇subscriptsuperscript~𝐹𝑏𝑖𝑤superscript𝒟′′superscript𝒟′𝒟∇subscriptsuperscript𝐹𝑏𝑖𝑤2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{p_{i}}\left\lVert\nabla\tilde{F}^{(b)}_{i}(w,\mathcal{D}^{\prime\prime},\mathcal{D}^{\prime},\mathcal{D})-\nabla F^{(b)}_{i}(w)\right\rVert^{2} ≤σb2,absentsuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝑏2\displaystyle\leq\sigma_{b}^{2}, (23)

for all w∈ℝd𝑤superscriptℝ𝑑w\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, where σb2≔3​(1+α​L)2​σg2​[1b+α2​L2b]+3​α2​G2​σh2b+3​α2​σg2​σh2b​[1b+α2​L2b]≔superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑏23superscript1𝛼𝐿2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑔2delimited-[]1𝑏superscript𝛼2superscript𝐿2𝑏3superscript𝛼2superscript𝐺2superscriptsubscript𝜎ℎ2𝑏3superscript𝛼2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑔2superscriptsubscript𝜎ℎ2𝑏delimited-[]1𝑏superscript𝛼2superscript𝐿2𝑏\sigma_{b}^{2}\coloneqq 3(1{+}\alpha L)^{2}\sigma_{g}^{2}\left[\frac{1}{b}{+}\frac{\alpha^{2}L^{2}}{b}\right]+3\alpha^{2}G^{2}\frac{\sigma_{h}^{2}}{b}+\frac{3\alpha^{2}\sigma_{g}^{2}\sigma_{h}^{2}}{b}\left[\frac{1}{b}{+}\frac{\alpha^{2}L^{2}}{b}\right].

Lemma 2 highlights two important results. First, the stochastic gradient in (9) is a biased estimation of the full gradient 5. The biasness is controlled by two factors, personalization stepsize α𝛼\alpha, and batch size b𝑏b.444It should be noted that the batch size in the upper bound of (22) refers to the size of |𝒟′|superscript𝒟′|\mathcal{D}^{\prime}|. Recall that we use this batch to approximate the inner gradient in 10. Therefore, we obtain an unbiased estimation under no personalization, i.e., α=0𝛼0\alpha=0. However, as we select a larger α𝛼\alpha, we require more samples to reduce the error imposed by biased gradient estimations. Second, similar to Assumption 3 on the cost; we have a tight variance based on α𝛼\alpha and b𝑏b.

Lemma 3 ([17], Lemma 4.4 - Bounded Population Diversity: MAML).

For all w∈ℝd𝑤superscriptℝ𝑑w\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, the gradients of local personalized functions Fi(b)​(w)subscriptsuperscript𝐹𝑏𝑖𝑤F^{(b)}_{i}(w) and the global function F(b)​(w)superscript𝐹𝑏𝑤F^{(b)}(w) satisfy the following property:

1n​∑i=1n∥∇Fi(b)​(w)−∇F(b)​(w)∥2≤γb2≔12​(1+α​L)2​[1+α2​L2]​γg2+12​α2​G2​γh2.1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇subscriptsuperscript𝐹𝑏𝑖𝑤∇superscript𝐹𝑏𝑤2superscriptsubscript𝛾𝑏2≔12superscript1𝛼𝐿2delimited-[]1superscript𝛼2superscript𝐿2superscriptsubscript𝛾𝑔212superscript𝛼2superscript𝐺2superscriptsubscript𝛾ℎ2\displaystyle\frac{1}{n}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}\left\lVert\nabla F^{(b)}_{i}(w)-\nabla F^{(b)}(w)\right\rVert^{2}\leq\gamma_{b}^{2}\coloneqq 12(1+\alpha L)^{2}\left[1+\alpha^{2}L^{2}\right]\gamma_{g}^{2}+12\alpha^{2}G^{2}\gamma_{h}^{2}. (24)

The above lemma determines the heterogeneity of the personalized gradients ∇Fi(b)​(w)∇superscriptsubscript𝐹𝑖𝑏𝑤\nabla F_{i}^{(b)}(w) based on the heterogeneity of gradient and Hessian. One can see the connection of this bound with 𝒪​(γg2)+α2​𝒪​(γh2)𝒪superscriptsubscript𝛾𝑔2superscript𝛼2𝒪superscriptsubscript𝛾ℎ2\mathcal{O}(\gamma_{g}^{2})+\alpha^{2}\mathcal{O}(\gamma_{h}^{2}), whereby setting α=0𝛼0\alpha=0, we recover the same heterogeneity in terms of 𝒪​(⋅)𝒪⋅\mathcal{O}(\cdot) notion.

Lemma 4 (Bounded-Gradient: MAML).

For all clients i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n], and any parameter w∈ℝd𝑤superscriptℝ𝑑w\in\mathbb{R}^{d},

∥∇Fi(b)​(w)∥≤Gb≔(1+α​L)​G.delimited-∥∥∇subscriptsuperscript𝐹𝑏𝑖𝑤subscript𝐺𝑏≔1𝛼𝐿𝐺\displaystyle\left\lVert\nabla F^{(b)}_{i}(w)\right\rVert\leq G_{b}\coloneqq(1{+}\alpha L)G. (25)

This lemma indicates that the bound on the norm of personalized gradients potentially increases under a larger personalization budget α𝛼\alpha.

Building upon the results in Lemmas 2-(25), we are now ready to present the convergence result for PersA-FL-MAML.

Theorem 2 (PersA-FL-MAML).

Let Assumptions 1-6 hold, α≥0𝛼0\alpha\geq 0, β=1𝛽1\beta=1, and η=1Q​Lb​T𝜂1𝑄subscript𝐿𝑏𝑇\eta=\frac{1}{Q\sqrt{L_{b}T}}. Then, the following property holds for the joint iterates of Algorithms 1 & 2 under Option B on Problem (4): for any timestep T≥64​Lb𝑇64subscript𝐿𝑏T\geq 64L_{b} at the server

1T​∑t=0T−1𝔼​∥∇F(b)​(wt)∥21𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇1𝔼superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇superscript𝐹𝑏superscript𝑤𝑡2\displaystyle\frac{1}{T}\sum\limits_{t=0}^{T{-}1}\mathbb{E}\left\lVert\nabla F^{(b)}(w^{t})\right\rVert^{2} ≤4​Lb​(F(b)​(w0)−f⋆)T+8​Lb​(σb2+γb2)Tabsent4subscript𝐿𝑏superscript𝐹𝑏superscript𝑤0superscript𝑓⋆𝑇8subscript𝐿𝑏superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑏2superscriptsubscript𝛾𝑏2𝑇\displaystyle\leq\frac{4\sqrt{L_{b}}\left(F^{(b)}(w^{0})-f^{\star}\right)}{\sqrt{T}}+\frac{8\sqrt{L_{b}}\left(\sigma_{b}^{2}+\gamma_{b}^{2}\right)}{\sqrt{T}}
+20​Q​Lb​(Gb2+σb2)​(τ2+1)T+4​Q​α2​L2​(1+α​L)2​σg2b.20𝑄subscript𝐿𝑏superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑏2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑏2superscript𝜏21𝑇4𝑄superscript𝛼2superscript𝐿2superscript1𝛼𝐿2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑔2𝑏\displaystyle+\frac{20\,QL_{b}\left(G_{b}^{2}{+}\sigma_{b}^{2}\right)\left(\tau^{2}{+}1\right)}{T}+\frac{4\,Q\alpha^{2}L^{2}(1{+}\alpha L)^{2}\sigma_{g}^{2}}{b}.

The proof of this theorem can be found in Appendix B. Theorem 2 shows a convergence rate of 𝒪​(1T)+𝒪​(τ2T)+𝒪​(α2​σg2b)𝒪1𝑇𝒪superscript𝜏2𝑇𝒪superscript𝛼2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑔2𝑏\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{T}}\right)+\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{\tau^{2}}{T}\right)+\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{\alpha^{2}\sigma_{g}^{2}}{b}\right) for PersA-FL algorithm under MAML setup. Now, let us compare this rate with the convergence rate of FedAsync and Per-FedAvg, as in Table 1. The last term in the above rate, i.e., 𝒪​(α2​σg2b)𝒪superscript𝛼2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑔2𝑏\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{\alpha^{2}\sigma_{g}^{2}}{b}\right) accounts for personalization with biased gradient estimation. Moreover, compared to Per-FedAvg, the second term of this rate is different, which accounts for the maximum delay in asynchronous updates.

To achieve the optimal complexity bound for the result in Theorem 2, we show how to choose the parameters T,b𝑇𝑏T,b based on the desired accuracy ε𝜀\varepsilon in the following corollary.

Corollary 1 (PersA-FL-MAML ε𝜀\varepsilon-convergence).

Suppose the conditions in Theorem 2 are satisfied. Algorithms 1 & 2 under Option B finds an ε𝜀\varepsilon first-order stationary solution for F(b)superscript𝐹𝑏F^{(b)} in (4) by setting T=𝒪​(ε−2)𝑇𝒪superscript𝜀2T=\mathcal{O}(\varepsilon^{-2}) and b=𝒪​(ε−1)𝑏𝒪superscript𝜀1b=\mathcal{O}(\varepsilon^{-1}) given a fixed personalization budget α≥0𝛼0\alpha\geq 0.

The result in Corollary 1 highlights the required communication and sample complexity for ε𝜀\varepsilon first-order stationary convergence. Moreover, note that the last expression in Theorem 2 can also be controlled through a combined stepsize α𝛼\alpha and batch size b𝑏b. This result is consistent with intuition, i.e., more samples are required to obtain a higher degree of personalization.

Next, we will present the analysis of PersA-FL-ME.

4.3 Personalized Asynchronous Federated Learning: Moreau Envelope Setup (Option C)

In this subsection, we show three technical lemmas on the bounded variance of stochasticity and heterogeneity as well as smoothness for ME formulation (6) and then present the convergence rate of PersA-FL for this personalization framework. The proof of all results in this subsection is provided in Appendix C.

First, we present the smoothness property of ME loss.

Lemma 5 (Smoothness: ME).

Let Assumption 2 holds and λ≥κ​L𝜆𝜅𝐿\lambda\geq\kappa L for some κ>1𝜅1\kappa>1. Then, Fi(c)subscriptsuperscript𝐹𝑐𝑖F^{(c)}_{i} in (6) is Lcsubscript𝐿𝑐L_{c}-smooth, where Lc=λκ−1subscript𝐿𝑐𝜆𝜅1L_{c}=\frac{\lambda}{\kappa{-}1}.

According to Lemma 5, we limit our exploration to λ>L𝜆𝐿\lambda>L which satisfies the smoothness constraint for the ME formulation. In fact, according to Appendix C, one can also see that originally, each Fi(c)​(⋅)subscriptsuperscript𝐹𝑐𝑖⋅F^{(c)}_{i}(\cdot) is λ​Lλ−L𝜆𝐿𝜆𝐿\frac{\lambda L}{\lambda{-}L}-smooth which is also smaller than Lc=λκ−1subscript𝐿𝑐𝜆𝜅1L_{c}=\frac{\lambda}{\kappa{-}1}. As we mentioned in Section 2, when λ→∞→𝜆\lambda\to\infty, ME framework converts to FL. The smoothness property in Lemma 5 is tight because, Lc→L→subscript𝐿𝑐𝐿L_{c}\to L if λ→∞→𝜆\lambda\to\infty.

Corollary 2 ([13], Proposition 1).

If λ≥2​L𝜆2𝐿\lambda\geq 2L, then Lemma 5 implies that Fi(c)subscriptsuperscript𝐹𝑐𝑖F^{(c)}_{i} in (6) is λ𝜆\lambda-smooth.

Lemma 6 (Bounded Variance: ME).

Let Assumptions 2 and 3 hold, λ≥κ​L𝜆𝜅𝐿\lambda\geq\kappa L (for some κ>1𝜅1\kappa>1), and the data batch 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} be randomly sampled according to data distribution pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i}. Then, the following properties hold for the stochastic personalized gradient ∇F~i(c)​(w,𝒟)∇subscriptsuperscript~𝐹𝑐𝑖𝑤𝒟\nabla\tilde{F}^{(c)}_{i}(w,\mathcal{D}): for all w∈ℝd𝑤superscriptℝ𝑑w\in\mathbb{R}^{d},

∥𝔼pi​[∇F~i(c)​(w,𝒟)−∇Fi(c)​(w)]∥delimited-∥∥subscript𝔼subscript𝑝𝑖delimited-[]∇subscriptsuperscript~𝐹𝑐𝑖𝑤𝒟∇subscriptsuperscript𝐹𝑐𝑖𝑤\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbb{E}_{p_{i}}\left[\nabla\tilde{F}^{(c)}_{i}(w,\mathcal{D})-\nabla F^{(c)}_{i}(w)\right]\right\rVert ≤μc≔λλ−L​ν,absentsubscript𝜇𝑐≔𝜆𝜆𝐿𝜈\displaystyle\leq\mu_{c}\coloneqq\frac{\lambda}{\lambda{-}L}\nu, (26)
𝔼pi​∥∇F~i(c)​(w,𝒟)−∇Fi(c)​(w)∥2subscript𝔼subscript𝑝𝑖superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇subscriptsuperscript~𝐹𝑐𝑖𝑤𝒟∇subscriptsuperscript𝐹𝑐𝑖𝑤2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{p_{i}}\left\lVert\nabla\tilde{F}^{(c)}_{i}(w,\mathcal{D})-\nabla F^{(c)}_{i}(w)\right\rVert^{2} ≤σc2≔2​λ2(λ−L)2​[σg2b+ν2].absentsuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝑐2≔2superscript𝜆2superscript𝜆𝐿2delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑔2𝑏superscript𝜈2\displaystyle\leq\sigma_{c}^{2}\coloneqq\frac{2\lambda^{2}}{\left(\lambda{-}L\right)^{2}}\left[\frac{\sigma_{g}^{2}}{b}+\nu^{2}\right]. (27)

This lemma is analogous to Lemma 2 in Subsection 4.2. In Lemma 6, we show an upper bound on the variance and bias of the stochastic gradient compared to the full gradient. Note that when λ→∞→𝜆\lambda\to\infty, we know that θ^i​(w)→w→subscript^𝜃𝑖𝑤𝑤\hat{\theta}_{i}(w)\to w. Therefore, by fixing θ~i​(w)=wsubscript~𝜃𝑖𝑤𝑤\tilde{\theta}_{i}(w)=w, it is guaranteed that ν=0𝜈0\nu=0, thus our gradient estimation becomes unbiased and the variance similar to (15).

Lemma 7 (Bounded Population Diversity: ME).

Let personalization hyperparameter λ≥7​L𝜆7𝐿\lambda\geq 7L. Then, for all w∈ℝd𝑤superscriptℝ𝑑w\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, the gradients of local personalized functions Fi(c)​(w)subscriptsuperscript𝐹𝑐𝑖𝑤F^{(c)}_{i}(w) and the global ME function F(c)​(w)superscript𝐹𝑐𝑤F^{(c)}(w) satisfy the following property:

1n​∑i=1n∥∇Fi(c)​(w)−∇F(c)​(w)∥2≤γc2≔16​λ2λ2−48​L2​γg2.1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇subscriptsuperscript𝐹𝑐𝑖𝑤∇superscript𝐹𝑐𝑤2superscriptsubscript𝛾𝑐2≔16superscript𝜆2superscript𝜆248superscript𝐿2superscriptsubscript𝛾𝑔2\displaystyle\frac{1}{n}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}\left\lVert\nabla F^{(c)}_{i}(w)-\nabla F^{(c)}(w)\right\rVert^{2}\leq\gamma_{c}^{2}\coloneqq\frac{16\lambda^{2}}{\lambda^{2}{-}48L^{2}}\gamma_{g}^{2}. (28)

Lemma 7 provides a bound on population diversity of ME as a factor of γg2superscriptsubscript𝛾𝑔2\gamma_{g}^{2}. Similar to what we explained so far, for λ→∞→𝜆\lambda\to\infty, the heterogeneity bound turns into γg2superscriptsubscript𝛾𝑔2\gamma_{g}^{2}.

Remark 2.

In the analysis for Theorem 3, we consider bounded population diversity as in Assumption 4, average bounded diversity. [13][Assumption 3] and [68][6.1.1 Assumptions and Preliminaries, (vii)] consider a slightly stronger version of this assumption, namely uniformly “bounded heterogeneity” which is defined as follows:

maxi∈[n]​supw∈ℝd∥∇fi​(w)−∇f​(w)∥2≤γg2.subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛subscriptsupremum𝑤superscriptℝ𝑑superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝑤∇𝑓𝑤2superscriptsubscript𝛾𝑔2\displaystyle\max_{i\in[n]}\sup_{w\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}\lVert\nabla f_{i}(w)-\nabla f(w)\rVert^{2}\leq\gamma_{g}^{2}. (29)

Under the modified assumption in (29), we can improve γc2≔16​λ2λ2−8​L2​γg2≔superscriptsubscript𝛾𝑐216superscript𝜆2superscript𝜆28superscript𝐿2superscriptsubscript𝛾𝑔2\gamma_{c}^{2}\coloneqq\frac{16\lambda^{2}}{\lambda^{2}{-}8L^{2}}\gamma_{g}^{2}.

Now, we present our convergence result of PersA-FL-ME under Assumption 1-4

Theorem 3 (PersA-FL-ME).

Let Assumptions 1-4 hold, λ≥7​L𝜆7𝐿\lambda\geq 7L, β=1𝛽1\beta=1, and η=1Q​Lc​T𝜂1𝑄subscript𝐿𝑐𝑇\eta=\frac{1}{Q\sqrt{L_{c}T}}. Then, the following property holds for the joint iterates of Algorithms 1 & 2 under Option C on Problem (6): for any timestep T≥288​Lc​(Q+7)​(τ+1)2𝑇288subscript𝐿𝑐𝑄7superscript𝜏12T\geq 288L_{c}(Q{+}7)(\tau{+}1)^{2} at the server

1T​∑t=0T−1𝔼​∥∇F(c)​(wt)∥21𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇1𝔼superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇superscript𝐹𝑐superscript𝑤𝑡2\displaystyle\frac{1}{T}\sum\limits_{t=0}^{T{-}1}\mathbb{E}\left\lVert\nabla F^{(c)}(w^{t})\right\rVert^{2} ≤4​Lc​(F(c)​(wt)−f⋆)T+8​Lc​(σc2+γc2)Tabsent4subscript𝐿𝑐superscript𝐹𝑐superscript𝑤𝑡superscript𝑓⋆𝑇8subscript𝐿𝑐superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑐2superscriptsubscript𝛾𝑐2𝑇\displaystyle\leq\frac{4\sqrt{L_{c}}\left(F^{(c)}(w^{t})-f^{\star}\right)}{\sqrt{T}}+\frac{8\sqrt{L_{c}}\left(\sigma_{c}^{2}+\gamma_{c}^{2}\right)}{\sqrt{T}}
+144​Lc​(1+Q)​(τ2+1)​(σc2+γg2)T+4​Q​λ2​ν2(λ−L)2.144subscript𝐿𝑐1𝑄superscript𝜏21superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑐2superscriptsubscript𝛾𝑔2𝑇4𝑄superscript𝜆2superscript𝜈2superscript𝜆𝐿2\displaystyle+\frac{144L_{c}(1{+}Q)(\tau^{2}{+}1)\left(\sigma_{c}^{2}+\gamma_{g}^{2}\right)}{T}+\frac{4Q\lambda^{2}\nu^{2}}{(\lambda{-}L)^{2}}.

Theorem 3 proposes a convergence rate of 𝒪​(1T)+𝒪​(τ2T)+𝒪​(λ2​ν2(λ−L)2)𝒪1𝑇𝒪superscript𝜏2𝑇𝒪superscript𝜆2superscript𝜈2superscript𝜆𝐿2\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{T}}\right)+\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{\tau^{2}}{T}\right)+\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{\lambda^{2}\nu^{2}}{(\lambda{-}L)^{2}}\right) for PersA-FL under ME formulation. Again, under the exact same reasoning as Lemma 6, we know that ν=0𝜈0\nu=0 when λ→∞→𝜆\lambda\to\infty, thus the convergence rate simply reduces to FedAsync with no personalization. Moreover, let us compare the convergence result in Theorem 3 with the rate of pFedMe [13] in Table 1. By comparing the last terms in both rates, 𝒪​(λ2​ν2(λ−L)2)𝒪superscript𝜆2superscript𝜈2superscript𝜆𝐿2\mathcal{O}\Big{(}\frac{\lambda^{2}\nu^{2}}{(\lambda{-}L)^{2}}\Big{)} and 𝒪​(λ2​(1b+ν2)(λ−L)2)𝒪superscript𝜆21𝑏superscript𝜈2superscript𝜆𝐿2\mathcal{O}\Big{(}\frac{\lambda^{2}\left(\frac{1}{b}+\nu^{2}\right)}{(\lambda{-}L)^{2}}\Big{)}, one can see that the additional term 1b1𝑏\frac{1}{b} in the convergence rate of pFedMe, implies that even under λ→∞→𝜆\lambda\to\infty (i.e., no personalization), the last term does not vanish unless we select large data batches, i.e., b=𝒪​(ε−1)𝑏𝒪superscript𝜀1b=\mathcal{O}(\varepsilon^{-1}). Therefore, from the personalization perspective, our analysis provides a tighter bound compared to pFedMe.

In the next corollary, we characterize a choice of T,ν𝑇𝜈T,\nu in Theorem 3, given a desired accuracy level ε𝜀\varepsilon for our proposed algorithm in Option C.

Corollary 3 (PersA-FL-ME ε𝜀\varepsilon-convergence).

Suppose the conditions in Theorem 3 are satisfied. Algorithms 1 & 2 under Option C finds an ε𝜀\varepsilon first-order stationary solution for F(c)superscript𝐹𝑐F^{(c)} in (6) by setting T=𝒪​(ε−2)𝑇𝒪superscript𝜀2T=\mathcal{O}(\varepsilon^{-2}) and ν=𝒪​(ε1/2)𝜈𝒪superscript𝜀12\nu=\mathcal{O}(\varepsilon^{{1}/{2}}) given a fixed personalization budget λ𝜆\lambda.

Corollary 1 determines the communication complexity and precision of the approximate gradient estimator to achieve an ε𝜀\varepsilon first-order stationary convergence. This means that if we choose ν=𝒪​(ε1/2)𝜈𝒪superscript𝜀12\nu=\mathcal{O}(\varepsilon^{{1}/{2}}), then the inexact optimization solver should compute the solution up to accuracy O​(ν)𝑂𝜈O(\nu) of the surrogate optimization problem in order to achieve an ε𝜀\varepsilon-first order stationary solution. Also, we would like to highlight that this result implies no direct dependence on the batch size (b) for the convergence result of our algorithm with Option C(cf. [13]).

5 Numerical Experiments

In this section, we evaluate the performance of our method in settings with delayed communications. We focus on the aspects of concurrency, speed-up, and accuracy.

Let us first start by explaining our simulation setup for communications with delays. We consider a set of n=30𝑛30n{=}30 different clients. Each of the clients has a set of random delays at the upload and download stage. The random delays are generated such that the average upload delay is 444 to 666 times higher than the average download delay. Moreover, we assume that the time for communication and aggregation is much larger than the time for local updates, thus we focus on the communication time. First, we show the number of active (not idle) users during the training process under asynchronous communications. The orange curve in Figure 2(a) shows the proportion of active users, which is up to 80%percent8080\% on average over time. We also plot the average proportion of users sampled in the synchronous updates in the same figure with green color. As Figure 2(a) demonstrates, the concurrency level for asynchronous methods is considerably higher than that of their synchronous counterparts.

We create extremely heterogeneous distributed data from MNIST [41] and CIFAR-10 [39] datasets for the clients, meaning that each client holds a different and skewed distribution of images from various classes. To build the heterogeneous data, we assign each client i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n] samples from only c𝑐c out of 101010 classes of the data. Over the underlying communication setup and heterogeneous data setting, we compare the speed and accuracy of FedAvg, Per-FedAvg, pFedMe, SCAFFOLD555Scaffold algorithm has two options. Option I makes another pass over the local data to compute the gradient at the server model. Therefore, we consider SCAFFOLD (Option I), which is more stable in practice [34]., FedAsync, PersA-FL-MAML, PersA-FL-ME, where the first four methods are synchronous and the rest are asynchronous. For MNIST and CIFAR-10, we consider convolutional networks [39] followed by fully connected layers with pooling and dropout as well as cross-entropy loss. Details on the experimental setups can be found in AppendixD.

Figure 2 (b) and Figure 2 (c) compares the performance and convergence speed of our methods (PersA-FL-MAML & PersA-FL-ME) with the other five algorithms respectively on heterogeneous MNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets. We would like to emphasize that in these two figures, each point on each curve represents the accuracy of the corresponding method after local fine-tuning with the same personalization budget as personalized personalized algorithm. In other words, similar to the four personalized methods, Per-FedAvg, pFedMe, PersA-FL-MAML, and PersA-FL-ME, we consider same amount of fine-tuning budget for the three non-personalized methods. FedAvg, SCAFFOLD, and FedAsync. As shown in Figure 2, our methods outperform the other methods within a fixed communication time. Moreover, the ME loss function results in a more stable and efficient performance compared to MAML.

6 Conclusion

This work studied the personalized federated learning problem for the heterogeneous data setting under asynchronous communications with the server. We considered the Model-Agnostic Meta-Learning (MAML) and Moreau Envelope (ME) formulations to account for personalization. We proposed the PersA-FL algorithm to solve this problem under stale updates. We showed the convergence rate of our method for smooth non-convex functions asynchronous federated learning, and personalized federated learning under the two personalization formulations, i.e., MAML and ME. Particularly, for asynchronous federated learning and personalized federated learning under Moreau Envelope costs, we presented a proof technique that does not require a boundedness assumption on the gradient norm. We finally show numerical results that illustrate the benefits of our proposed method in terms of accuracy and scalability. The studies of generalization and communication efficiency will be left to future research. Moreover, the extensions of our method to the buffered aggregation and decentralized setups remain for future studies.

Appendix D Experiments Setting

For all algorithms, we consider Q=10𝑄10Q=10 local updates, and select the best λ∈{20,25,30}𝜆202530\lambda\in\{20,25,30\} for ME and α∈{0.002,0.005,0.01}𝛼0.0020.0050.01\alpha\in\{0.002,0.005,0.01\} for MAML. Moreover, we pick β∈{0.8,1.0,1.2}𝛽0.81.01.2\beta\in\{0.8,1.0,1.2\} and fix η=0.01𝜂0.01\eta=0.01. For all experiments, we consider the exact same communication setup and repeat each experiment 222 to 333 times and plot the test accuracy curve over time until one of the algorithms converges. We consider n=30𝑛30n=30 agents for all experiments. Moreover, for both datasets we consider ℓℓ\ell-layer CNN networks [39] followed by ℓℓ\ell-fully connected layers with pooling and dropout as well as cross-entropy loss, where ℓ=2ℓ2\ell=2 for MNIST and ℓ=3ℓ3\ell=3 for CIFAR-10. Also, for MNIST we consider c=5𝑐5c=5 class of samples for each client while for CIFAR we create heterogeneity by considering c=3𝑐3c=3 per client.

It is worth mentioning that in the implementation of algorithms with MAML, we approximated the Hessian-vector products via the following first-order formulation: for some small δ>0𝛿0\delta>0,

∇2fi​(w)​u≈∇fi​(w+δ​u)−∇fi​(w−δ​u)δ.superscript∇2subscript𝑓𝑖𝑤𝑢∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝑤𝛿𝑢∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝑤𝛿𝑢𝛿\displaystyle\nabla^{2}f_{i}(w)u\approx\frac{\nabla f_{i}(w+\delta u)-\nabla f_{i}(w-\delta u)}{\delta}. (224)

Moreover, in the bi-level optimization problem for the ME formulation, we applied a constant K=10𝐾10K=10 steps of SGD to obtain θ~i​(w)subscript~𝜃𝑖𝑤\tilde{\theta}_{i}(w).
